ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Great class, very practical, very useful!
I don't plan on a career of financial modeling for natural resources, but I still think that this is important material for understanding timber sales and ecosystem services.
Great real-world perspective from a practitioner in the field.
The professor has "real world" experience that I appreciate and I enjoy her presentation of the material. I am thankful she takes the time to teach.
The course material of forest finance is very valuable to students, evident from the number of studentsin the course.

I think that a smaller room would have been helpful. Also, there was a wide range of familiarity with excel in the class, and the time spent discussing different functions in excel (especially different ways to do the same thing) wasn't nearly as useful to meas the underlying principle.

Not all readings were clearly useful in the context of the assignments. For instance, the practical readings such as Binkley and Cubbage were really helpful, but the USDA and broader credit trading documents were marginally useful.

In response to the pace of the course: I think this course should be either geared towards first years and in that case it is fine, or towards second years and the pace and depth of material could be increased.
Q12. This was the most professonally useful course I took this semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Great experience with excel assignments and hands-on skills.

Learning about financial tools and how to use them to build predictions about the value of your land and its evolution depending on your management decisions (thinning, road construction...) was extremely useful. Really liked how the homework had us apply the concepts to real life situations.
It is practical.

For me this was a "connective" course--it linked other courses I have taken for the MF (silviculture, econ, forest operations) in a very practical way.Deborah's practical experience in the field she is teaching makes her a credible and expert instructor.
I really enjoyed the case assignments. They forced me to apply the concepts we learned in class and helped develop a different skill set than is required for other forestry focused classes.
The problem sets were excellent.
Real world anecdotes interspersed with theoretical presentation.
The real world situations that our Professor spoke to us about. She was able to put these concepts into context, and talkabout real deals that her company has done.
Good presentation of material (powerpoint).Enjoyed focus on timber AND ecosystem services.The teaching assistant, Spenser, did an excellent job. It was helpful to hear his experience and thoughts.
Gaining a basic understanding of finance concepts, forestland investment, and environmental markets.Learning from a practitioner.
The course is a valuable part of the curriculum. I wish there was a more advanced option as a follow-on.

- Learning from a practitioner- Instructor and TA very accessible, open to student questions and participation- Valuable practice modeling NPV of various timber and mitigation credit investment projects

The professors personal experience, the very applicable content, the practical skills gained, the interactive and real-world assignments, the pulled-from-industry publications reading, the clear slides.

The best aspect of this course was the explanation of basic financial valuation principles as they apply to forests and ecosystem services. Understanding how to do a rudimentary analysis of this in excel was also important, mostly because it will allow us to read these analyses better in the future.
The assignments were fun and clearly applicable.
Getting to listen to Deborah share real world experience. Learning nifty tricks on excel.
The homework assignments.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: None.
Change the location. Deborah Spalding was obviously frustrated by the lack of interaction induced by Bowers' airport-like dimensions.
I felt like there were too many readings. It also would have been helpful if we were given a quick primer on financial terms to be used in the class.
I would have appreciated more discussion between students
I think a more round-table discussion style would be best. Numbers forced us to a larger room unfortunately
Readings could be streamlined
I think this course would benefit from some discussions every once and awhile. Three hours of lecture can be a challenge to focus the entire time.

The return time on assignments was really unacceptable.Better classroom location.Prompt start to lecture.Textbook?More "real world" examples of property appraisals and investments.Final project revision.

Better readings - Im not very familiar with this field so I don't know if better reading material is out there, but I didn't find the course readings extremely helpful. Most seemed to come from land appraisal and didn't provide the basic background to the concept in question. Considering that the course is relatively introductory, some popular nonfiction about conservation finance might have well timed.Student presentations - see 16Perhaps team - teach with someone like B. Gentry or B. Cashore, or at the very least, bring some specialists to guest lecture the topics that Deb is less familiar with. Deb has really valuable experience as a practitioner, but limited knowledge about some aspects of conservation finance because she is not a full time professor and just doesn't have the time.Two lectures / week is probably better than one.
The instructor used mostly outdated slides and market outlooks. Most material was pre-2008 and irrelevant in today's markets. Current data is widely available.
More guidance on bigger projects like the final one would have helped melearn more from the experience

Focus on excel as a tool, not the focus of the study. Also, I don't know if there's a way to address some more of the students' reservations about the inherent environmental validity of wetland mitigation banking as it's practiced, but that would have helped me remain engaged.
Integration of readings.
Never teach this course in Bowers again and cap enrollment.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The TA was great ! ! !
n/a
n/a
N/A
N/A

It might have been good to do a session of student presentations regarding some topic of conservation finance - so many students had some experience in the field, and it would have been interesting to learn of them.
It woudl be great to havea couple discussion sessions on the reading - or to take a look at more case studies during class to pull together concepts - maybe a guest speaker instead of a field trip

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I actually sat in Kotchen's class during the first week of the semester and soon realized that I couldn't possibly take one more economics class as general as that (I've taken quite a few). Forest Finance is the finance class that every MF student should be required to take. It ties ecological concepts with financial mechanisms and gives us a clear notion of how investors interact to shape the market.
I am interested primarily in forest management. This course provided a look in to how management can affect the forest's value.
The information presented in this class is essential for all MFs and MEMs interested in forest management or policy.
Essential information on the financial side of things for forestry students.
Central, leads to career objective
Very applicable.
I am dual MF - MBA, so it was great for me to get an intro to conservation finance.

I am not studying forestry or even conservation management, but it is useful to understand how a company might go about valuating ecosystem services. Further, the course provides the opportunity to develop/practice modeling investment payback scenarios; which is a transferable skill to any kind of investment valuation (energy, infrastructure, etc)

This course might be the most improtant one I take at FES- I wish it were two semesters long so we could go more in depth. It is exactly the type ofthing I was hoping to learn when coming here. IT managed to mix the financial and environmental aspects of conservation without compromising either. Some classes when studying where these two things come together you dont end up studying much of all. Not the case here. Really hands on and applied - I would suggest stressing that more in future iterations of the course.
I'm an MF.
FES needs more forest finance offerings.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To explore innovative financing mechanisms for nature conservation. Also to learn how to calculate NPVs for timber resources.

Yale's take on forestry often errs on the qualitative side (at least compared to European forestry) and I learned by experience that if you don't have the numbers to back you up, your management prescriptions will not be heard. I wanted to be able to look at somebody's model and have a notion of whether it is valid or not.
See Q 17.
Because I see finance as a crucial practical subject for my career interests.
I need a background in forest finance for my hopeful future career
Well at first for the economic requirement, but I quickly realized how eye-opening this class was. I had never before taken any economic/financial courses.
Topic is of interest and good review of Deborah.
To better understand financial concepts and learn how basic financial modeling skills. Even though I'm not a forester, I think these skills are crucial for any environmental manager.
To better understand forest management from a financial perspective.
To gain a foundation in conservation finance.
to gain more knowledge of financial concepts and spreadsheet modeling, which FES curriculum lacks
To better understand ecosystem services and practice financial modeling.
I want to work in helping to create incentives for conservation on working land in the US
Mark Ashton said to.
The opportunity to take a course taught by Deborah. Real world applicability.
I'm interested in understanding how valuation of ecosystem services might occur in Latin America. This class was an exellent introduction, although appropriately U.S. focused.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Yes. Although I would have liked us to spend more time on timber value and timber growth modeling (including yield&growth).
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, I learned a lot and really enjoyed the class
Way beyond expectations.
Yes
yes!
Yes. Given the range of prior finance experience among students, I understand that some aspects of the course were kept simplistic but at times I felt the approach was too "dumbed-down".
It was a good introduction - we could have gone into more detail in the ancillary topics of carbon, PES, etc. This is a growing field of conservation finance.
yes.
Yes
Yes - maybe another week or two on ecosystem services/mitigation banking/ carbon would havebeen helpful
Yes.
yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it if you want to explore the world of conservation easements, property appraisals, wetland credits, and everything out there in the "real world" undertaken to make nature conservation somewhat financially feasible.
Don't let yourself be intimidated by the syllabus. You do not need to be proficient in either Excel of financial modeling in order to take this class.
Get ready to read and use excel!

Make sure that you start the assignments early. The readings can be long but they are really helpful for understanding concepts that may not be discussed in depth in class, depending upon other students interested. Be sure to share your interests with Deborah. She is wonderful at incorporating a wide variety of interests into class.
Ask questions.
Keep up with the readings and make time to meet with Deborah outside class.
Previous experience with excel is helpful but not required.
Yes - its a good intro to conservation finance. Bring your ideas for course material bc the instructor is very receptive.
Great course, very relevant syllabus, timely and emerging topics, but poor lectures. Don't take it with current instructor.
Take the course
Do it
Allow lots of extra time for the homework assignments. Those four or five hours you think you'll need are only half of what you could put into it.
Very good look at how finance evaluates forest value
Do the reading.
